Implicit Dynamical Flow Fusion (IDFF) for Generative Modeling

Mohammad R. Rezaei Department of Biomedical Engineering, University of Toronto Rahul G. Krishnan Vector Institute Department of Computer Science, University of Toronto Milos R. Popovic Department of Biomedical Engineering, University of Toronto KITE Research Institute, Toronto Rehabilitation Institute Milad Lankarany Department of Biomedical Engineering, University of Toronto KITE Research Institute, Toronto Rehabilitation Institute
Abstract

Conditional Flow Matching (CFM) models can generate high-quality samples from a non-informative prior but they can be slow, often needing hundreds of network evaluations (NFE). To address this, we propose Implicit Dynamical Flow Fusion (IDFF); IDFF learns a new vector field with an additional momentum term that enables taking longer steps during sample generation while maintaining the fidelity of the generated distribution. Consequently, IDFFs reduce the NFEs by a factor of ten (relative to CFMs) without sacrificing sample quality, enabling rapid sampling and efficient handling of image and time-series data generation tasks. We evaluate IDFF on standard benchmarks such as CIFAR-10 and CelebA for image generation. We achieved comparable likelihood and quality performance to CFMs and diffusion-based models with many fewer NFEs. IDFF also shows superior performance on time-series datasets modeling, including molecular simulation and sea surface temperature (SST) datasets, highlighting its versatility and effectiveness across different domains.

1 Introduction

Diffusion models (Ho etÂ al., 2020; Cachay etÂ al., 2023; Myers etÂ al., 2022) have gained significant traction in modeling complex, high-dimensional data by iteratively transforming random noise into meaningful data. These models have been successfully applied in diverse fields, such as generating high-quality images (Song etÂ al., 2020a) and text (Liu etÂ al., 2024; Kim etÂ al., 2019). However, the training process is computationally intensive, requiring numerous steps of sampling (Ho etÂ al., 2020; Song etÂ al., 2020b). Specifically, diffusion models require hundreds of function evaluations (NFEs) to achieve high-quality results. Techniques such as DPM-solver (Lu etÂ al., 2022a, b) and Denoising Diffusion Implicit Models (DDIMs) (Song etÂ al., 2020b) address help reduce the NFE for diffusion-based generative models. While diffusion models parameterize the dynamics that transform noise into data, Conditional Flow Matching (CFMs) (Li etÂ al., 2022; Tong etÂ al., 2023; Liu etÂ al., 2022; Albergo and Vanden-Eijnden, 2022; Albergo etÂ al., 2023) directly parameterize vector fields that govern transformation from noise to data. CFMs define conditional probability paths through the change of variable theory in statistics (Lipman etÂ al., 2022), enabling faster convergence during training compared to diffusion models (Lipman etÂ al., 2022).

Generating high-quality samples with CFMs requires hundreds of NFEs; this makes the process computationally expensive (Dao etÂ al., 2023; Lipman etÂ al., 2022) and restricts the extension of CFM models to time-series data modeling since the NFE scale with the length of the sequence.

To overcome these challenges, we introduce a novel method to improve the efficiency of CFMs, allowing for longer sampling steps without compromising the fidelity of the target distribution. Our approach is inspired by Hamiltonian Monte Carlo (HMC) algorithms (Neal etÂ al., 2011; Neal, 2012), which utilize the conservation properties of Hamiltonian dynamics to couple the target and momentum variables.

The contributions of our work are as follows:

  1. 1.

    We propose the Implicit Dynamical Flow Fusion (IDFF), which integrates a momentum term into the vector field of conditional flow models. Similar to how HMC reduces the number of samples required to reach the target distribution (Neal, 2012; Hoffman etÂ al., 2014), IDFF reduces the NFE by a factor of 10 compared to traditional CFMs while maintaining identical marginal distributions. Additionally, we introduce a training objective that directly aligns the generated samples with the actual data rather than solely focusing on matching the conditional flows.

  2. 2.

    We validate IDFF through extensive experiments on image generation using datasets such as CIFAR-10 and CelebA. Additional results on ImageNet-64, CelebA-HQ, LSUN-Church, and LSUN-Bedroom are presented in Figure 1. Our models achieve a superior balance between computational cost and sample quality compared to both traditional diffusion models (e.g., DDPM (Ho etÂ al., 2020), DDIM (Song etÂ al., 2020b)) and current CFMs (Pooladian etÂ al., 2023; Tong etÂ al., 2023).

  3. 3.

    We show that reducing NFEs makes IDFF practical for other generation tasks, such as time-series modeling. We demonstrate IDFFâ€™s effectiveness in capturing complex dynamical systems, including 3D attractors, molecular dynamics (MD), and sea surface temperatures (SST). Our results indicate that IDFF surpasses other methods regarding sample quality for MD and SST datasets while maintaining computational efficiency, with NFE â‰¤\leq 5 for each generated sample.

The training objective defined in 5 guarantees that the marginalized ğ¯^tâ€‹(ğ±|ğ±1)subscript^ğ¯ğ‘¡conditionalğ±subscriptğ±1\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1}), ğ¯^tâ€‹(ğ±)subscript^ğ¯ğ‘¡ğ±\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}), generates ptâ€‹(ğ±)subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ±p_{t}({\mathbf{x}}) as FM models do, and thus allows easy sampling of unbiased estimates as long as we can efficiently sample from ptâ€‹(ğ±|ğ±1)subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡conditionalğ±subscriptğ±1p_{t}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1}) and compute ğ¯^tâ€‹(ğ±|ğ±1)subscript^ğ¯ğ‘¡conditionalğ±subscriptğ±1\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1}), both of which can be done as they are defined on a per-sample basis (Lipman etÂ al., 2022).

CFMs share conceptual similarities with diffusion models, as both frameworks rely on defining continuous probability paths over time. While diffusion models use stochastic processes to transform data distributions, typically governed by an SDE as seen in (Song etÂ al., 2020b; Ho etÂ al., 2020), CFMs utilize a deterministic vector field to create a conditional flow that directly maps an initial prior distribution to the target distribution via an ODE. Diffusion models, such as denoising score matching models, rely on stochastic diffusion paths to approximate the data distribution. At the same time, CFMs bypass this stochastic process by constructing a conditional vector field and sampling from an ODE to generate samples (Lipman etÂ al., 2022; Song etÂ al., 2020a).

The CFM objective defined in Equation 5 appears simple. However, it is nearly intractable due to the absence of prior knowledge regarding an appropriate coupling term between the initial (p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0}) and target (p1subscriptğ‘1p_{1}) distributions. To address this challenge, optimal transport (OT) (Pooladian etÂ al., 2023; Lipman etÂ al., 2022) is used to couple the initial and target distributions. This term seeks a mapping from p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0} to p1subscriptğ‘1p_{1} that minimizes the displacement cost between these two distributions, resulting in flows that can be integrated accurately. This CFM variant is Optimal Transport CFMs (OT-CFMs)(Tong etÂ al., 2023). Although OT improves the efficiency of training in CFMs, as shown in Figure 2, traditional sampling methods for OT-CFMs still require more than a hundred function evaluations (NFE) to generate high-quality samples (Dao etÂ al., 2023; Tong etÂ al., 2023).

As shown in Pooladian etÂ al. (2023), the vector field associated with the conditional vector field ğ¯^tâ€‹(ğ±t|ğ±1)=ğ±1âˆ’ğ±1âˆ’tsubscript^ğ¯ğ‘¡conditionalsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡subscriptğ±1subscriptğ±1ğ±1ğ‘¡\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}_{t}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1})=\frac{{\mathbf{x}}_{1}-{\mathbf{x}}}{1-t} can be expressed as ğ¯^tâ€‹(ğ±t|ğ±1)=ğ±1âˆ’ğ±0subscript^ğ¯ğ‘¡conditionalsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡subscriptğ±1subscriptğ±1subscriptğ±0\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}_{t}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1})={\mathbf{x}}_{1}-{\mathbf{x}}_{0}. It becomes a deterministic function when conditioned on ğ±0subscriptğ±0{\mathbf{x}}_{0}. Consequently, using any deterministic solver and conditioning on the initial points ğ±0subscriptğ±0{\mathbf{x}}_{0}, the sample generation process becomes deterministic, which limits the generalizability of the conditional OT-CFM models compared to the stochastic processes employed in denoising diffusion models. Moreover, as flow matching learns ğ¯^tâ€‹(ğ±t|ğ±1)subscript^ğ¯ğ‘¡conditionalsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡subscriptğ±1\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}_{t}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1}), there is no flexibility in the sampling steps during the training phase. This restriction on sampling, constrained to the integration steps, hinders the ability of OT-CFMs to generate high-quality samples with a small number of integration steps, often leading to a high NFE during the sampling process.

3 Implicit dynamical flow fusion model (IDFF)

Increasing the sampling steps to improve generative efficiency in FMs while preserving the target distributionâ€™s accuracy is crucial. To achieve this, we introduce a learnable Hamiltonian momentum term, denoted as ğƒtsubscriptğƒğ‘¡\bm{\xi}_{t}, into the vector field ğ¯^tsubscript^ğ¯ğ‘¡\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t} and define a new vector field for FMs as:

When Ïƒtsubscriptğœğ‘¡\sigma_{t} is set sufficiently close to 0 for t={0,1}ğ‘¡01t=\{0,1\}, ğ¯~tâ€‹(ğ±)subscript~ğ¯ğ‘¡ğ±\tilde{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}) converges to the standard ğ¯^tâ€‹(ğ±)subscript^ğ¯ğ‘¡ğ±\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}), ensuring the same marginal distributions at t=0ğ‘¡0t=0 and t=1ğ‘¡1t=1 as in CFMs. As demonstrated here, incorporating such an auxiliary variable into Langevin sampling methods aligns with well-established HMC simulated sampling methods. This strategy reduces the steps required to achieve a high-fidelity distribution Hoffman etÂ al. (2014); Neal (2012).

3.1 Training Objective for IDFF

As the CFM literature outlines, learning a conditional vector field ğ¯^tâ€‹(ğ±|ğ±1)subscript^ğ¯ğ‘¡conditionalğ±subscriptğ±1\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1}) is faster and preserves the same marginals. Consequently, we can define the conditional probability OT path ptâ€‹(ğ±|ğ±1)subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡conditionalğ±subscriptğ±1p_{t}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1}) to act as a probability bridge between a source point ğ±0subscriptğ±0{\mathbf{x}}_{0} and a target point ğ±1subscriptğ±1{\mathbf{x}}_{1} (Tong etÂ al., 2023; Lipman etÂ al., 2022).

An efficient approach to selecting the probability path pt(.)p_{t}(.) from a displacement perspective is to choose the path with minimal displacement between p0(.)p_{0}(.) and p1(.)p_{1}(.) by defining it as a stochastic interpolator between ğ±1subscriptğ±1{\mathbf{x}}_{1} and ğ±0subscriptğ±0{\mathbf{x}}_{0}, given by:

ptâ€‹(ğ±|ğ±1)=ğ’©â€‹(ğ±âˆ£tâ€‹ğ±1+(1âˆ’t)â€‹ğ±0,Ïƒt2â€‹I),Ïƒt=Ïƒ0â€‹tâ€‹(1âˆ’t)formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡conditionalğ±subscriptğ±1ğ’©conditionalğ±ğ‘¡subscriptğ±11ğ‘¡subscriptğ±0superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘¡2Isubscriptğœğ‘¡subscriptğœ0ğ‘¡1ğ‘¡p_{t}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1})=\mathcal{N}({\mathbf{x}}\mid t{\mathbf{x}}_{1}+(1-t){\mathbf{x}}_{0},\sigma_{t}^{2}\textbf{I}),\ \ \sigma_{t}=\sigma_{0}\sqrt{t(1-t)} (8)
ğ¯^tâ€‹(ğ±|ğ±1)=ğ±1âˆ’ğ±1âˆ’tsubscript^ğ¯ğ‘¡conditionalğ±subscriptğ±1subscriptğ±1ğ±1ğ‘¡\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1})=\frac{{\mathbf{x}}_{1}-{\mathbf{x}}}{1-t} (9)

This definition aligns with the conditional OT paths between ğ±1subscriptğ±1{\mathbf{x}}_{1} and ğ±0subscriptğ±0{\mathbf{x}}_{0}, which have an equivalent conditional probability flow to the marginal pt(.)p_{t}(.) of flow ğ¯^t(.)\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}(.) (Pooladian etÂ al., 2023).

For large datasets, computing this OT map can be challenging (Cuturi, 2013; Tong etÂ al., 2020). A minibatch approximation of OT, similar to (Fatras etÂ al., 2021), can address this. While minibatch OT introduces some errors compared to the exact OT solution, it has proven effective in numerous applications such as domain adaptation and generative modeling (Genevay etÂ al., 2018). Therefore, we use minibatch OT to approximate the map between ğ±0subscriptğ±0{\mathbf{x}}_{0} and ğ±1subscriptğ±1{\mathbf{x}}_{1}.

Current CFM objectives utilize the loss function defined in equation 5, which optimizes the prediction of the vector field. Instead of directly learning ğ¯^tâ€‹(ğ±âˆ£ğ±1;Î¸)subscript^ğ¯ğ‘¡conditionalğ±subscriptğ±1ğœƒ\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}\mid{\mathbf{x}}_{1};\theta) using equation 5, we propose defining a denoising neural network ğ±^1â€‹(ğ±,t;Î¸)subscript^ğ±1ğ±ğ‘¡ğœƒ\hat{{\mathbf{x}}}_{1}({\mathbf{x}},t;\theta) and reparameterizing ğ¯^tâ€‹(ğ±âˆ£ğ±1;Î¸)subscript^ğ¯ğ‘¡conditionalğ±subscriptğ±1ğœƒ\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}\mid{\mathbf{x}}_{1};\theta) as follows:

ğ¯^tâ€‹(ğ±âˆ£ğ±1;Î¸)=ğ±^1â€‹(ğ±,t;Î¸)âˆ’ğ±1âˆ’tsubscript^ğ¯ğ‘¡conditionalğ±subscriptğ±1ğœƒsubscript^ğ±1ğ±ğ‘¡ğœƒğ±1ğ‘¡\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}\mid{\mathbf{x}}_{1};\theta)=\frac{\hat{{\mathbf{x}}}_{1}({\mathbf{x}},t;\theta)-{\mathbf{x}}}{1-t} (10)

3.2 IDFF time-series adaptation and sampling process

To use IDFF for time-series applications, we need to modify the training and sampling algorithms for IDFF. This conditioning does not change the original assumption over tğ‘¡t since kğ‘˜k can take any values up to the time-series length with the sample probability. Note that for static data, the sequence length (Kğ¾K) equals one; otherwise, it equals the time series length.

For a fixed K=1ğ¾1K=1, once we have trained ğ±^1(.;Î¸)\hat{{\mathbf{x}}}_{1}(.;\theta) and Ïµ(.;Î¸)\bm{\epsilon}(.;\theta), we can generate samples simulated by an SDE from source samples ğ±0subscriptğ±0{\mathbf{x}}_{0}. 4 Related Work

Our proposed IDFF model extends state-of-the-art generative modeling techniques, particularly diffusion models such as denoising diffusion probabilistic models (DDPMs) (Ho etÂ al., 2020) and CFMs. DDPMs rely on SDEs and Langevin dynamics for sampling (Yan etÂ al., 2021), while CFMs use deterministic ODE solvers to sample from learned vector fields. Both methods are effective at generating high-quality samples but require many iterations, leading to computational inefficiency.

To address these limitations, denoising diffusion implicit models (DDIMs)(Song etÂ al., 2020b) were introduced, offering a more efficient sampling process by deterministically generating samples from latent variables. Unlike DDPMs, which rely on Langevin dynamics, DDIMs employ a variational approach that accelerates sampling while preserving output quality.

In the realm of CFMs, recent advancements include SchrÃ¶dinger-based methods (Richter etÂ al., 2023) and conjugate/splitting-based integrators (Pandey etÂ al., 2023), which aim to improve sampling efficiency. However, these methods still struggle to significantly reduce the NFEs, a key factor for computational efficiency. Other approaches to enhance sampling in diffusion-based generative models include the generalized Schrodinger bridge, which seeks stochastic evolution between prior and target distributions (Richter etÂ al., 2023), and distillation frameworks like Flash (Kohler etÂ al., 2024), which offer diverse sample generation in fewer steps by addressing training-inference discrepancies.

IDFF builds upon these developments and introduces several key improvements. Rather than directly learning vector fields like CFMs, IDFF focuses on learning the evolving samples ğ’™tsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡\bm{x}_{t} at each time step. It implicitly constructs the vector field during sampling through a reparameterization approach (Eq. 10). By incorporating a momentum term and a scoring model, IDFF allows for larger sampling steps, reducing NFE by up to a factor of 10 compared to CFMs, as illustrated in Figure 2.

A distinguishing feature of IDFF is its ability to jointly learn an implicit flow from the generated samples alongside the scoring model, setting it apart from models like DDIM, which focuses solely on learning a scoring function. By leveraging OT to couple samples between t=0ğ‘¡0t=0 and t=1ğ‘¡1t=1, IDFF accelerates convergence during training while maintaining low NFE and improving sample quality. It is evident from our image generation experiments (Tables 1 and 2). In comparisons with DDPM, DDIM, and DPM-Solver (another model that improves the NFEs for diffusion models)Lu etÂ al. (2022a), IDFF consistently demonstrates superior efficiency and quality.

In conclusion, IDFF integrates the strengths of implicit flow and score-based learning, offering a novel and efficient framework for generative modeling that significantly reduces computational costs while producing high-quality samples.

5 Experiments

We conducted two general classes of experiments to demonstrate the effectiveness of IDFF in generative modeling on static data, such as images and time-series data, including simulated chaotic systems (e.g., attractors), molecular dynamics, and sea surface temperature forecasting.

5.1 Image Generation

In this section, we showcase the superior performance of IDFF compared to CFMs in image generation, especially in the number of function evaluations (NFE). We trained IDFF models on datasets such as CIFAR-10 and CelebA (additional results for ImageNet-64, CelebA-HQ, LSUN Bedrooms, and LSUN Church are available in Appendix A.2). We utilized a CNN-based UNet (ADM) (Dhariwal and Nichol, 2021) to simultaneously model both ğ±^1(.,t;Î¸)\hat{{\mathbf{x}}}_{1}(.,t;\theta) and Ïµ(.,t;Î¸)\bm{\epsilon}(.,t;\theta) from Equation 11 for all image data except ImageNet-64. For ImageNet-64, we employed a DiT architecture (â€™DiT-L/4â€™)(Peebles and Xie, 2022). To implement this, we doubled the input channels of the networks and fed the augmented input, (ğ±t,ğ±t)subscriptğ±ğ‘¡subscriptğ±ğ‘¡({\mathbf{x}}_{t},{\mathbf{x}}_{t}), into the network. The outputs were then split into (ğ±^1(.,t;Î¸),Ïµ(.,t;Î¸))(\hat{{\mathbf{x}}}_{1}(.,t;\theta),\bm{\epsilon}(.,t;\theta)).

To ensure a fair comparison with other models, we used commonly employed metrics to evaluate CFMsâ€™ performance, including negative log-likelihood (NLL) measured in bits per dimension (BPD), sample quality as measured by the Frechet Inception Distance (FID), and the average NFE required for the reported FID and NLL, averaged over 50k samples, to assess the computational efficiency of our method. We generate 50k images to calculate the FID against the corresponding reference statistics of each dataset. All models use the same architecture, with specific details provided in Appendix A.1.4.

We also examined the effect of Ïƒ0subscriptğœ0\sigma_{0} on sample quality for both CIFAR-10 and CelebA datasets in Appendix A.1.3, finding that a value of Ïƒ0=0.6subscriptğœ00.6\sigma_{0}=0.6 achieved the best FID for both datasets, as shown in Table 1 and Table 2. IDFF achieves comparable FID scores with ten times fewer NFEs than CFM and DDPM on the CIFAR-10 and CelebA datasets. IDFFâ€™s qualitative results are provided in Figure 1 (additional samples are available in Appendix A.2).

Figure 4 (A) displays the FID score for the initial 50k generated samples plotted against NFEs for both the CIFAR-10 and CelebA datasets. Sample quality improves rapidly when the NFE exceeds 4, highlighting the significantly lower sampling cost of IDFF compared to traditional CFMs and diffusion-based models.

5.2 Time Series Generation

To assess the performance of IDFF in modeling time series data, we evaluated IDFF on three distinct tasks: 3D-attractor generation (see Appendix A.3), molecular dynamics simulation, and sea surface temperature forecasting.

5.2.1 Molecular Dynamics Simulation

Molecular dynamics simulation is a crucial tool in quantum mechanics for understanding the dynamics of molecular behavior at the atomic level (Cazorla and Boronat, 2017). Here, we simulated a fully extended polyalanine structure for 400 picoseconds in a vacuum environment at a temperature of T=300â€‹Kğ‘‡300ğ¾T=300K.

This molecular structure consists of 253 atoms with 46 dihedral angles. We trained an IDFF model to accurately generate the dihedral angles for the polyalanine structure from scratch. The distributions of the actual and generated dihedral angles for all 46 angles are presented in Figure 3 (A) and (B), respectively. Figure 3 (C) illustrates the dihedral angles for one of the alanine molecules and its associated dihedral angles. A complete trajectory showcasing a pair of actual and generated dihedral angles is depicted in Figure 3 (D).

To assess the performance of IDFF in the MD simulation, we utilized several evaluation metrics, including root mean squared error (RMSE), mean absolute error (MAE), and correlation coefficients (CC) between the generated and actual trajectories of dihedral angles. We benchmarked IDFF against well-known dynamical models for time series, including dynamical VAE models such as SRNNs (Fraccaro etÂ al., 2016), VRNNs (Chung etÂ al., 2015), and Neural ODEs (NODEs) (Garnelo etÂ al., 2018). As shown in Table 3, IDFF outperforms the baselines by a large margin, indicating its great potential for simulating molecular dynamics from scratch.

5.2.2 Sea Surface Temperature Forecasting

This experiment focuses on forecasting sea surface temperature (SST). Based on NOAA OISSTv2, our dataset consists of daily weather images with high-resolution SST data from 1982 to 2021 (Cachay etÂ al., 2023). We created a refined dataset for forecasting SST intervals from 1 to 7 days ahead by strategically subsampling eleven grid tiles of size 60Ã—60606060\times 60 (latitude Ã—\times longitude) in the eastern tropical Pacific region (Huang etÂ al., 2021).

We used a class-conditional UNet (ADM) for the SST experiment, with the class encoder part encoding the long-range time dependencies (i.e., for encoding the days) to allow continuous forecasting using the UNet (ADM). See Appendix A.1.4 for the experimentâ€™s network structure and hyperparameter settings. We used the training 1 and sampling 2 algorithms suggested for time-series data. We evaluated the performance of IDFF using the best validation continuous ranked probability score (CRPS) (Matheson and Winkler, 1976) and mean squared error (MSE) on forecasts up to 7 days. CRPS is a proper scoring rule and a popular metric in probabilistic forecasting literature (Gneiting and Katzfuss, 2014). We calculate the CRPS by generating a 20-member ensemble and the MSE on the ensemble mean predictions in Table 4. To assess IDFFâ€™s performance, we compared it against various baseline approaches, including DDPM, DDPM with enabled dropout (Dropout) (Gal and Ghahramani, 2016), DDPM with random perturbation for the initial values (Perturbation) (Pathak etÂ al., 2022), MCVD (Voleti etÂ al., 2022), Dyffusion (Cachay etÂ al., 2023), and OT-CFM (with Nâ€‹Fâ€‹E=40ğ‘ğ¹ğ¸40NFE=40) as shown in Table 4. The results for all the baselines are with Nâ€‹Fâ€‹E=1000ğ‘ğ¹ğ¸1000NFE=1000. These baselines provide a robust framework for evaluating the IDFF framework in time-series forecasting. For more details about the SST dataset and experiment, refer to (Cachay etÂ al., 2023). The results show that IDFF (with Nâ€‹Fâ€‹E=5ğ‘ğ¹ğ¸5NFE=5) outperforms the baselines in SST forecasting across both metrics, demonstrating great potential for weather forecasting applications. See samples of the forecasting results in Figure 13.

6 Conclusion

IDFF models represent a significant advancement in generative modeling, particularly for time series data, by offering superior computational efficiency compared to traditional flow models like CFMs. The enhanced efficiency and favorable trade-offs between computational cost and sample quality make IDFF a top choice for tasks requiring efficient and high-quality sample generation. Furthermore, IDFF has the potential to extend to other domains, such as music generation (Briot etÂ al., 2017), speech synthesis (Yu and Deng, 2016), and the generation of noisy biological time-series data (Anumanchipalli etÂ al., 2019; Golshan etÂ al., 2020).

One limitation of IDFF pertains to the definition of OT plans, where the computational cost escalates with batch size, resulting in longer training times, especially for large batches. Additionally, while the ADM structure was primarily employed in our experiments, generating large-scale time series data, such as videos, could benefit from utilizing more recent backbone structures as proposed in (Ho etÂ al., 2022; Peebles and Xie, 2023) to enhance efficiency further.

Broader Impacts and Limitations.

IDFF models offer a computationally efficient alternative to traditional flow models like CFMs, enabling faster generation of high-quality samples. This efficiency makes them practical for various applications, suggesting that IDFF could become a preferred choice for generative modeling tasks that demand both efficiency and high sample quality at a lower computational cost. However, it is crucial to establish safeguards and incentives to prevent the misuse of this technology. Care must be taken to ensure that the synthetic data generated by this technology is used following societal norms and ethical standards.

Moreover, IDFF could have broader implications across various fields and should be considered a generic framework that can extend applications such as music generation (Briot etÂ al., 2017), speech generation (Yu and Deng, 2016), and other forms of noisy biological time-series data (Rezaei etÂ al., 2021, 2023; Anumanchipalli etÂ al., 2019; Golshan etÂ al., 2020; Gracco etÂ al., 2005).

NeurIPS Paper Checklist

  1. 1.

    Claims

  2. Question: Do the main claims made in the abstract and introduction accurately reflect the paperâ€™s contributions and scope?

  3. Answer: [Yes]

  4. Justification: The paper provides evidence for all the claims made in the abstract mainly in the experiments section.

  5. Guidelines:

    • â€¢

      The answer NA means that the abstract and introduction do not include the claims made in the paper.

    • â€¢

      The abstract and/or introduction should clearly state the claims made, including the contributions made in the paper and important assumptions and limitations. A No or NA answer to this question will not be perceived well by the reviewers.

    • â€¢

      The claims made should match theoretical and experimental results, and reflect how much the results can be expected to generalize to other settings.

    • â€¢

      It is fine to include aspirational goals as motivation as long as it is clear that these goals are not attained by the paper.

  6. 2.

    Limitations

  7. Question: Does the paper discuss the limitations of the work performed by the authors?

  8. Answer: [Yes]

  9. Justification: See the conclusion section

  10. Guidelines:

    • â€¢

      The answer NA means that the paper has no limitation while the answer No means that the paper has limitations, but those are not discussed in the paper.

    • â€¢

      The authors are encouraged to create a separate "Limitations" section in their paper.

    • â€¢

      The paper should point out any strong assumptions and how robust the results are to violations of these assumptions (e.g., independence assumptions, noiseless settings, model well-specification, asymptotic approximations only holding locally). The authors should reflect on how these assumptions might be violated in practice and what the implications would be.

    • â€¢

      The authors should reflect on the scope of the claims made, e.g., if the approach was only tested on a few datasets or with a few runs. In general, empirical results often depend on implicit assumptions, which should be articulated.

    • â€¢

      The authors should reflect on the factors that influence the performance of the approach. For example, a facial recognition algorithm may perform poorly when image resolution is low or images are taken in low lighting. Or a speech-to-text system might not be used reliably to provide closed captions for online lectures because it fails to handle technical jargon.

    • â€¢

      The authors should discuss the computational efficiency of the proposed algorithms and how they scale with dataset size.

    • â€¢

      If applicable, the authors should discuss possible limitations of their approach to address problems of privacy and fairness.

    • â€¢

      While the authors might fear that complete honesty about limitations might be used by reviewers as grounds for rejection, a worse outcome might be that reviewers discover limitations that arenâ€™t acknowledged in the paper. The authors should use their best judgment and recognize that individual actions in favor of transparency play an important role in developing norms that preserve the integrity of the community. Reviewers will be specifically instructed to not penalize honesty concerning limitations.

  11. 3.

    Theory Assumptions and Proofs

  12. Question: For each theoretical result, does the paper provide the full set of assumptions and a complete (and correct) proof?

  13. Answer: [Yes]

  14. Justification: We provided proof for our method.

  15. Guidelines:

    • â€¢

      The answer NA means that the paper does not include theoretical results.

    • â€¢

      All the theorems, formulas, and proofs in the paper should be numbered and cross-referenced.

    • â€¢

      All assumptions should be clearly stated or referenced in the statement of any theorems.

    • â€¢

      The proofs can either appear in the main paper or the supplemental material, but if they appear in the supplemental material, the authors are encouraged to provide a short proof sketch to provide intuition.

    • â€¢

      Inversely, any informal proof provided in the core of the paper should be complemented by formal proofs provided in appendix or supplemental material.

    • â€¢

      Theorems and Lemmas that the proof relies upon should be properly referenced.

  16. 4.

    Experimental Result Reproducibility

  17. Question: Does the paper fully disclose all the information needed to reproduce the main experimental results of the paper to the extent that it affects the main claims and/or conclusions of the paper (regardless of whether the code and data are provided or not)?

  18. Answer: [Yes]

  19. Justification: See the experiment and method sections.

  20. Guidelines:

    • â€¢

      The answer NA means that the paper does not include experiments.

    • â€¢

      If the paper includes experiments, a No answer to this question will not be perceived well by the reviewers: Making the paper reproducible is important, regardless of whether the code and data are provided or not.

    • â€¢

      If the contribution is a dataset and/or model, the authors should describe the steps taken to make their results reproducible or verifiable.

    • â€¢

      Depending on the contribution, reproducibility can be accomplished in various ways. For example, if the contribution is a novel architecture, describing the architecture fully might suffice, or if the contribution is a specific model and empirical evaluation, it may be necessary to either make it possible for others to replicate the model with the same dataset, or provide access to the model. In general. releasing code and data is often one good way to accomplish this, but reproducibility can also be provided via detailed instructions for how to replicate the results, access to a hosted model (e.g., in the case of a large language model), releasing of a model checkpoint, or other means that are appropriate to the research performed.

    • â€¢

      While NeurIPS does not require releasing code, the conference does require all submissions to provide some reasonable avenue for reproducibility, which may depend on the nature of the contribution. For example

      1. (a)

        If the contribution is primarily a new algorithm, the paper should make it clear how to reproduce that algorithm.

      2. (b)

        If the contribution is primarily a new model architecture, the paper should describe the architecture clearly and fully.

      3. (c)

        If the contribution is a new model (e.g., a large language model), then there should either be a way to access this model for reproducing the results or a way to reproduce the model (e.g., with an open-source dataset or instructions for how to construct the dataset).

      4. (d)

        We recognize that reproducibility may be tricky in some cases, in which case authors are welcome to describe the particular way they provide for reproducibility. In the case of closed-source models, it may be that access to the model is limited in some way (e.g., to registered users), but it should be possible for other researchers to have some path to reproducing or verifying the results.

  21. 5.

    Open access to data and code

  22. Question: Does the paper provide open access to the data and code, with sufficient instructions to faithfully reproduce the main experimental results, as described in supplemental material?

  23. Answer: [Yes]

  24. Justification: Upon acceptance of the paper, we provided the GitHub repository enabling the reproduction of all the results presented in the paper.

  25. Guidelines:

    • â€¢

      The answer NA means that paper does not include experiments requiring code.

    • â€¢

      Please see the NeurIPS code and data submission guidelines (https://nips.cc/public/guides/CodeSubmissionPolicy) for more details.

    • â€¢

      While we encourage the release of code and data, we understand that this might not be possible, so â€œNoâ€ is an acceptable answer. Papers cannot be rejected simply for not including code, unless this is central to the contribution (e.g., for a new open-source benchmark).

    • â€¢

      The instructions should contain the exact command and environment needed to run to reproduce the results. See the NeurIPS code and data submission guidelines (https://nips.cc/public/guides/CodeSubmissionPolicy) for more details.

    • â€¢

      The authors should provide instructions on data access and preparation, including how to access the raw data, preprocessed data, intermediate data, and generated data, etc.

    • â€¢

      The authors should provide scripts to reproduce all experimental results for the new proposed method and baselines. If only a subset of experiments are reproducible, they should state which ones are omitted from the script and why.

    • â€¢

      At submission time, to preserve anonymity, the authors should release anonymized versions (if applicable).

    • â€¢

      Providing as much information as possible in supplemental material (appended to the paper) is recommended, but including URLs to data and code is permitted.

  26. 6.

    Experimental Setting/Details

  27. Question: Does the paper specify all the training and test details (e.g., data splits, hyperparameters, how they were chosen, type of optimizer, etc.) necessary to understand the results?

  28. Answer: [Yes]

  29. Justification: The experiment section and appendices fully support this.

  30. Guidelines:

    • â€¢

      The answer NA means that the paper does not include experiments.

    • â€¢

      The experimental setting should be presented in the core of the paper to a level of detail that is necessary to appreciate the results and make sense of them.

    • â€¢

      The full details can be provided either with the code, in appendix, or as supplemental material.

  31. 7.

    Experiment Statistical Significance

  32. Question: Does the paper report error bars suitably and correctly defined or other appropriate information about the statistical significance of the experiments?

  33. Answer: [Yes]

  34. Justification: See the result tables 4, 3

  35. Guidelines:

    • â€¢

      The answer NA means that the paper does not include experiments.

    • â€¢

      The authors should answer "Yes" if the results are accompanied by error bars, confidence intervals, or statistical significance tests, at least for the experiments that support the main claims of the paper.

    • â€¢

      The factors of variability that the error bars are capturing should be clearly stated (for example, train/test split, initialization, random drawing of some parameter, or overall run with given experimental conditions).

    • â€¢

      The method for calculating the error bars should be explained (closed form formula, call to a library function, bootstrap, etc.)

    • â€¢

      The assumptions made should be given (e.g., Normally distributed errors).

    • â€¢

      It should be clear whether the error bar is the standard deviation or the standard error of the mean.

    • â€¢

      It is OK to report 1-sigma error bars, but one should state it. The authors should preferably report a 2-sigma error bar than state that they have a 96% CI, if the hypothesis of Normality of errors is not verified.

    • â€¢

      For asymmetric distributions, the authors should be careful not to show in tables or figures symmetric error bars that would yield results that are out of range (e.g. negative error rates).

    • â€¢

      If error bars are reported in tables or plots, The authors should explain in the text how they were calculated and reference the corresponding figures or tables in the text.

  36. 8.

    Experiments Compute Resources

  37. Question: For each experiment, does the paper provide sufficient information on the computer resources (type of compute workers, memory, time of execution) needed to reproduce the experiments?

  38. Answer: [Yes]

  39. Justification: See Table5

  40. Guidelines:

    • â€¢

      The answer NA means that the paper does not include experiments.

    • â€¢

      The paper should indicate the type of compute workers CPU or GPU, internal cluster, or cloud provider, including relevant memory and storage.

    • â€¢

      The paper should provide the amount of compute required for each of the individual experimental runs as well as estimate the total compute.

    • â€¢

      The paper should disclose whether the full research project required more compute than the experiments reported in the paper (e.g., preliminary or failed experiments that didnâ€™t make it into the paper).

  41. 9.

    Code Of Ethics

  42. Question: Does the research conducted in the paper conform, in every respect, with the NeurIPS Code of Ethics https://neurips.cc/public/EthicsGuidelines?

  43. Answer: [Yes]

  44. Justification: We reviewed the NeurIPS Code of Ethics.

  45. Guidelines:

    • â€¢

      The answer NA means that the authors have not reviewed the NeurIPS Code of Ethics.

    • â€¢

      If the authors answer No, they should explain the special circumstances that require a deviation from the Code of Ethics.

    • â€¢

      The authors should make sure to preserve anonymity (e.g., if there is a special consideration due to laws or regulations in their jurisdiction).

  46. 10.

    Broader Impacts

  47. Question: Does the paper discuss both potential positive societal impacts and negative societal impacts of the work performed?

  48. Answer: [Yes]

  49. Justification: The papers societal impacts are discussed in the last section of the paper.

  50. Guidelines:

    • â€¢

      The answer NA means that there is no societal impact of the work performed.

    • â€¢

      If the authors answer NA or No, they should explain why their work has no societal impact or why the paper does not address societal impact.

    • â€¢

      Examples of negative societal impacts include potential malicious or unintended uses (e.g., disinformation, generating fake profiles, surveillance), fairness considerations (e.g., deployment of technologies that could make decisions that unfairly impact specific groups), privacy considerations, and security considerations.

    • â€¢

      The conference expects that many papers will be foundational research and not tied to particular applications, let alone deployments. However, if there is a direct path to any negative applications, the authors should point it out. For example, it is legitimate to point out that an improvement in the quality of generative models could be used to generate deepfakes for disinformation. On the other hand, it is not needed to point out that a generic algorithm for optimizing neural networks could enable people to train models that generate Deepfakes faster.

    • â€¢

      The authors should consider possible harms that could arise when the technology is being used as intended and functioning correctly, harms that could arise when the technology is being used as intended but gives incorrect results, and harms following from (intentional or unintentional) misuse of the technology.

    • â€¢

      If there are negative societal impacts, the authors could also discuss possible mitigation strategies (e.g., gated release of models, providing defenses in addition to attacks, mechanisms for monitoring misuse, mechanisms to monitor how a system learns from feedback over time, improving the efficiency and accessibility of ML).

  51. 11.

    Safeguards

  52. Question: Does the paper describe safeguards that have been put in place for responsible release of data or models that have a high risk for misuse (e.g., pretrained language models, image generators, or scraped datasets)?

  53. Answer: [N/A]

  54. Justification: The paper presents a methodological approach to learning diffusion models. It is not instantiated on problems with very large datasets such as ImageNet and ThePile.

  55. Guidelines:

    • â€¢

      The answer NA means that the paper poses no such risks.

    • â€¢

      Released models that have a high risk for misuse or dual-use should be released with necessary safeguards to allow for controlled use of the model, for example by requiring that users adhere to usage guidelines or restrictions to access the model or implementing safety filters.

    • â€¢

      Datasets that have been scraped from the Internet could pose safety risks. The authors should describe how they avoided releasing unsafe images.

    • â€¢

      We recognize that providing effective safeguards is challenging, and many papers do not require this, but we encourage authors to take this into account and make a best faith effort.

  56. 12.

    Licenses for existing assets

  57. Question: Are the creators or original owners of assets (e.g., code, data, models), used in the paper, properly credited and are the license and terms of use explicitly mentioned and properly respected?

  58. Answer: [Yes]

  59. Justification: All datasets used from other sources are properly referenced in the paper.

  60. Guidelines:

    • â€¢

      The answer NA means that the paper does not use existing assets.

    • â€¢

      The authors should cite the original paper that produced the code package or dataset.

    • â€¢

      The authors should state which version of the asset is used and, if possible, include a URL.

    • â€¢

      The name of the license (e.g., CC-BY 4.0) should be included for each asset.

    • â€¢

      For scraped data from a particular source (e.g., website), the copyright and terms of service of that source should be provided.

    • â€¢

      If assets are released, the license, copyright information, and terms of use in the package should be provided. For popular datasets, paperswithcode.com/datasets has curated licenses for some datasets. Their licensing guide can help determine the license of a dataset.

    • â€¢

      For existing datasets that are re-packaged, both the original license and the license of the derived asset (if it has changed) should be provided.

    • â€¢

      If this information is not available online, the authors are encouraged to reach out to the assetâ€™s creators.

  61. 13.

    New Assets

  62. Question: Are new assets introduced in the paper well documented and is the documentation provided alongside the assets?

  65. Guidelines:

    • â€¢

    • â€¢

      The paper should discuss whether and how consent was obtained from people whose asset is used.

    • â€¢

      At submission time, remember to anonymize your assets (if applicable). You can either create an anonymized URL or include an anonymized zip file.

  66. 14.

    • â€¢

A.1.3 Balancing the IDFF flow

IDFF consists of a scoring model and an implicit flow component coupled with a parameter Ïƒ0subscriptğœ0\sigma_{0} to generate flow ğ°(.)\bm{{\mathbf{w}}}(.). We examine the effect of Ïƒ0subscriptğœ0\sigma_{0} on sample quality for the CIFAR-10 and CelebA datasets, with the NFE fixed at 10. As shown in Figure 4 (B), a value of Ïƒ0=0.6subscriptğœ00.6\sigma_{0}=0.6 achieves the best balance between the diffusion and flow components regarding sample quality for both datasets. This plot also demonstrates that sample quality is susceptible to Ïƒ0subscriptğœ0\sigma_{0}, particularly for diffusion-based models like DDPMs, compared to CFMs, especially at small NFEs, which is already noticed in some research[Jolicoeur-Martineau etÂ al., 2020, Jain etÂ al., 2020].

A.2 Additional results for image generation experiment

A.3 3D-attractors

In this experiment, we assess IDFFâ€™s performance in generating trajectories of chaotic systems from scratch. We generate trajectories with K=2000ğ¾2000K=2000 samples in each trajectory from 3D attractors, specifically the Lorenz and RÃ¶ssler attractors, which are chaotic systems with nonlinear dynamics. The parameters for the Lorenz and RÃ¶ssler models are set to Ïƒ=10,Ï=28,Î²=8/3formulae-sequenceğœ10formulae-sequenceğœŒ28ğ›½83{\sigma=10,\rho=28,\beta=8/3} and a=.2,b=.2,c=5.7formulae-sequenceğ‘.2formulae-sequenceğ‘.2ğ‘5.7{a=.2,b=.2,c=5.7}, respectively, to produce complex trajectories in 3D space. We then train the IDFF model based on these trajectories. To model each attractor, we use an MLP with two hidden layers of 128 dimensions and two separate heads for ğ±^1(.,t,k;Î¸)\hat{{\mathbf{x}}}_{1}(.,t,k;\theta) and Ïµâ€‹(ğ±,t,k;Î¸)italic-Ïµğ±ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğœƒ\epsilon({\mathbf{x}},t,k;\theta). Additionally, we incorporate two separate embedding layers for embedding tğ‘¡t and kğ‘˜k, which are directly concatenated with the first hidden layer of the MLP. The optimized IDFF successfully generates samples of these trajectories from scratch. The generated trajectories are shown in Figure 12. The quality of the results demonstrates that IDFF can successfully simulate the behaviors of highly nonlinear and nonstationary systems such as attractors.
